tasks.title: Setup Google Calendar API and OAuth Credentials
tasks.description: Configure Google Calendar API and OAuth 2.0 credentials for integration.
tasks.details: Create a Google API project and set up OAuth 2.0 credentials. Configure the consent screen and obtain client ID and secret for the application.
tasks.testStrategy: Verify OAuth credentials by initiating a test OAuth flow and ensuring successful authentication.

subtasks.title: Create Google API Project
subtasks.description: Set up a new project in the Google Cloud Console to enable Google Calendar API.
subtasks.details: Log in to the Google Cloud Console. Navigate to the 'Select a project' dropdown and click 'New Project'. Enter a project name and select an organization if applicable. Click 'Create' to set up the project.
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify the project creation by checking the project list in the Google Cloud Console.

subtasks.title: Enable Google Calendar API
subtasks.description: Enable the Google Calendar API for the newly created project.
subtasks.details: In the Google Cloud Console, select the created project. Navigate to 'APIs & Services' > 'Library'. Search for 'Google Calendar API' and click on it. Click 'Enable' to activate the API for your project.
subtasks.testStrategy: Confirm the API is enabled by checking the 'Enabled APIs & Services' section.

subtasks.title: Configure OAuth Consent Screen
subtasks.description: Set up the OAuth consent screen for the application to define how it will appear to users.
subtasks.details:
In the Google Cloud Console, go to 'APIs & Services' > 'OAuth consent screen'. Choose 'External' for user type if the app is for public use. Fill out the required fields such as App name, User support email, and Developer contact information. Save the changes.
<info added on 2025-08-08T09:53:26.516Z>
Confirmed that the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Flow is the correct approach for multi-user calendar integration. Each user will authenticate with their own Google account and grant calendar permissions. Proceed with configuring the OAuth consent screen accordingly.
</info added on 2025-08-08T09:53:26.516Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Ensure the consent screen is configured by reviewing the summary page after saving.

subtasks.title: Create OAuth 2.0 Credentials
subtasks.description: Generate OAuth 2.0 credentials to allow the application to access Google Calendar API on behalf of users.
subtasks.details: Navigate to 'APIs & Services' > 'Credentials' in the Google Cloud Console. Click 'Create Credentials' and select 'OAuth client ID'. Choose 'Web application' as the application type. Enter a name and configure the authorized redirect URIs. Click 'Create' to obtain the client ID and secret.
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify the credentials by checking the 'Credentials' page for the newly created client ID and secret.

subtasks.title: Test OAuth Flow
subtasks.description: Initiate a test OAuth flow to ensure the credentials are correctly set up and the application can authenticate users.
subtasks.details:
Develop a simple test application or script that uses the client ID and secret to initiate an OAuth flow. Redirect users to Google's OAuth consent screen and handle the callback to exchange the authorization code for an access token.
<info added on 2025-08-08T10:08:29.632Z>
Create a separate OAuth flow on the /today page with a "Connect" button that requests calendar-specific scopes. Ensure the flow prompts users for permissions related to calendar access and integrates seamlessly with the existing authentication process.
</info added on 2025-08-08T10:08:29.632Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Perform the OAuth flow and verify successful authentication by checking for a valid access token and user information retrieval.

tasks.title: Design Database Schema for Calendar Integration
tasks.description: Evaluate the need for additional database schema for calendar integration.
tasks.details: Assess whether the existing NextAuth Account table is sufficient for storing Google Calendar OAuth tokens and if fetching events directly from the Google Calendar API meets current requirements. If additional schema is necessary, implement the provided SQL schema for 'calendar_integrations' and 'calendar_events' tables, ensuring proper indexing and foreign key constraints.
tasks.testStrategy: Review current implementation and run database migration scripts only if new tables are deemed necessary. Verify the creation of tables with correct schema if implemented.

subtasks.title: Evaluate Current Schema Sufficiency
subtasks.description: Analyze if the existing NextAuth Account table and direct API fetching are sufficient for current calendar integration needs.

subtasks.title: Implement Additional Schema if Necessary
subtasks.description: If additional schema is required, implement the SQL schema for 'calendar_integrations' and 'calendar_events' tables.

tasks.title: Implement OAuth Flow Endpoints
tasks.description: Develop backend endpoints to handle Google OAuth flow for calendar integration.
tasks.details: Create endpoints: GET /api/calendar/auth/google, POST /api/calendar/auth/callback. Use OAuth libraries to manage token exchange and storage.
tasks.testStrategy: Test OAuth flow by simulating user authentication and verifying token storage in the database.

tasks.title: Build Calendar Event Fetching Service
tasks.description: Develop a service to fetch calendar events from Google API.
tasks.details: Implement a service that uses Google API client libraries to fetch events. Handle pagination and store events in the database.
tasks.testStrategy: Unit test the service with mock API responses to ensure correct data fetching and storage.

tasks.title: Create Calendar Drawer Component
tasks.description: Develop a frontend component for displaying calendar events in a drawer.
tasks.details: Build a responsive calendar drawer component using existing UI frameworks. Ensure it slides in from the right side of the /today page.
tasks.testStrategy: Perform UI testing to ensure the drawer component displays correctly on various screen sizes.

tasks.title: Implement Calendar Toggle Button
tasks.description: Add a toggle button to the /today page to open the calendar drawer.
tasks.details: Place a toggle button in the header of the /today page. Ensure it triggers the opening and closing of the calendar drawer component.
tasks.testStrategy: Test the toggle functionality to ensure it correctly opens and closes the calendar drawer.

tasks.title: Develop Day View Calendar Component
tasks.description: Create a day view component to display calendar events in hourly slots.
tasks.details: Implement a day view similar to Google Calendar's, showing events with titles, times, and durations. Use existing UI patterns for consistency.
tasks.testStrategy: Validate the component by comparing event display with actual Google Calendar data for accuracy.

tasks.title: Implement Error Handling and Loading States
tasks.description: Add error handling and loading states for calendar data fetching.
tasks.details: Implement UI states for loading and error scenarios. Ensure graceful degradation when API calls fail or are slow.
tasks.testStrategy: Simulate API failures and slow responses to test the robustness of error handling and loading states.

tasks.title: Optimize Performance with Caching Layer
tasks.description: Implement a caching layer to reduce API calls and improve performance.
tasks.details: Use in-memory caching to store calendar events for 15-30 minutes. Ensure cache invalidation and refresh mechanisms are in place.
tasks.testStrategy: Measure API call reduction and verify cache hit rates during testing.

tasks.title: Conduct Comprehensive Testing and User Feedback
tasks.description: Perform end-to-end testing and gather user feedback for the calendar integration.
tasks.details: Conduct unit, integration, and E2E tests. Collect user feedback through surveys and usability testing sessions.
tasks.testStrategy: Analyze test results and user feedback to identify areas for improvement before final deployment.

tasks.title: Setup Project Repository
tasks.description: Initialize the project repository for WhatsApp integration.
tasks.details: Create a new Git repository for the WhatsApp integration project. Set up the initial project structure with directories for server, client, and shared resources. Initialize package.json for dependency management and configure ESLint and Prettier for code quality.
tasks.testStrategy: Verify repository setup by cloning and building the project locally.

subtasks.title: Create Git Repository

subtasks.title: Set Up Project Structure

subtasks.title: Initialize package.json

subtasks.details: Use npm to initialize package.json and add necessary scripts.
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify package.json by installing a test package and checking node_modules.

subtasks.title: Configure ESLint

tasks.title: Implement WhatsApp Business Account Setup

tasks.details: Create a user interface to guide users through the WhatsApp Business Account setup, including Facebook Business Manager integration and phone number verification. Use React for the frontend and Node.js for backend API endpoints.
tasks.testStrategy: Test the setup flow with a test WhatsApp Business Account to ensure all steps are completed successfully.

subtasks.description: Develop the user interface for the settings page where users can initiate the WhatsApp Business Account setup.
subtasks.details:
Use React to create a settings page UI that includes input fields and buttons for initiating the WhatsApp Business Account setup. Follow the existing design pattern used for the Slack integration settings page. Ensure the UI is responsive and user-friendly.
<info added on 2025-08-09T13:53:04.089Z>
Add WhatsApp as a provider option in IntegrationsClient.tsx. Create a form for manual credential entry, including fields for Access Token, Phone Number ID, Business Account ID, and Webhook Verify Token. Follow the existing Slack manual setup pattern where users enter credentials obtained from Meta Business Manager.

Successfully implemented the `createWhatsAppIntegration` mutation in the integration router. </info added on 2025-08-09T14:07:59.108Z>

Implement Webhook Verification Endpoint - Create /api/webhooks/whatsapp/route.ts to handle Meta webhook verification. Implement GET request handler for webhook verification challenge, implement POST handler for incoming messages, add signature verification for security. All endpoints follow existing patterns and include proper authentication and error handling.

subtasks.testStrategy: Test API endpoints using Postman to ensure data is correctly saved and retrieved.

subtasks.testStrategy: Perform connection tests to ensure the system can successfully send test messages and receive confirmation.

tasks.title: Implement OAuth Integration Flow
tasks.description: Implement authentication for WhatsApp using permanent System User Access Tokens from Meta Business Manager.
tasks.details: Use the Facebook Graph API to manage System User Access Tokens for WhatsApp Business. Securely store these tokens using encryption and ensure they are handled securely. Support multiple WhatsApp Business accounts per user without using OAuth.
tasks.testStrategy: Perform end-to-end testing to ensure System User Access Tokens are correctly issued, stored, and managed securely. Verify multi-account support and token encryption.

tasks.title: Develop Webhook Handler for Incoming Messages
tasks.description: Create a webhook handler to process incoming WhatsApp messages.
tasks.details: Implement a webhook endpoint to receive and process incoming messages from WhatsApp. Verify webhook signatures for security and handle all supported message types. Use Express.js for the server setup.
tasks.testStrategy: Simulate incoming messages using WhatsApp's sandbox environment and verify correct processing and logging.

subtasks.title: Set Up Express.js Server
subtasks.description: Initialize an Express.js server to handle incoming HTTP requests.
subtasks.details:
Create a new Node.js project and install Express.js. Set up a basic server that listens on a specified port. Ensure the server is capable of handling POST requests, which will be used for receiving webhook data.
<info added on 2025-08-09T16:42:02.402Z>
The webhook endpoint has been implemented using Next.js API routes instead of Express.js. The endpoint is located at /api/webhooks/whatsapp/route.ts.
</info added on 2025-08-09T16:42:02.402Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Start the server and use a tool like Postman to send a test POST request to ensure the server is running and can handle requests.

subtasks.title: Implement Webhook Endpoint
subtasks.description: Create an endpoint to receive incoming messages from WhatsApp.
subtasks.details:
Define a new route in the Express.js server to act as the webhook endpoint. This route should accept POST requests and log the incoming data for initial verification.
<info added on 2025-08-09T16:42:12.908Z>
The webhook endpoint has been created at /api/webhooks/whatsapp/route.ts with both GET (for webhook verification) and POST (for receiving messages) handlers.
</info added on 2025-08-09T16:42:12.908Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Use WhatsApp's sandbox environment to send a test message to the webhook endpoint and verify that the message is received and logged correctly.

subtasks.title: Verify Webhook Signatures
subtasks.description: Implement security measures to verify the authenticity of incoming messages using webhook signatures.
subtasks.details:
Use the appropriate library or custom code to verify the signature of incoming requests. This typically involves using a shared secret to validate the signature included in the request headers.
<info added on 2025-08-09T16:45:53.967Z>
Successfully implemented webhook signature verification. Added database token verification for webhook challenge, implemented HMAC-SHA256 signature verification for incoming messages using the app secret (access token), and verified the signature against Meta's x-hub-signature-256 header.
</info added on 2025-08-09T16:45:53.967Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Send requests with both valid and invalid signatures to ensure that only requests with valid signatures are processed.

subtasks.title: Handle Supported Message Types
subtasks.description: Develop logic to process different types of messages received from WhatsApp.
subtasks.details:
Identify all supported message types (e.g., text, image, video) and implement handlers for each type. Ensure that each handler extracts relevant information and processes it accordingly.
<info added on 2025-08-09T16:46:13.617Z>
The webhook handler now supports all major WhatsApp message types: text, image, document, audio, video, location, and contacts. Each type has its own processing function that extracts relevant data and stores it in the database using the storeWhatsAppMessage procedure.
</info added on 2025-08-09T16:46:13.617Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Simulate sending different types of messages from WhatsApp's sandbox and verify that each type is correctly processed and logged.

subtasks.title: Integrate Logging and Error Handling
subtasks.description: Add logging and error handling to the webhook handler for better monitoring and debugging.
subtasks.details:
Implement a logging mechanism to record incoming requests and processing results. Add error handling to manage unexpected issues gracefully, ensuring that errors are logged and do not crash the server.
<info added on 2025-08-09T16:46:25.673Z>
The webhook handler now includes comprehensive logging using console.log for all incoming requests. Error handling is implemented with try-catch blocks throughout, ensuring that errors are logged to the console for debugging. The handler always returns a 200 OK status to prevent WhatsApp from retrying failed requests.
</info added on 2025-08-09T16:46:25.673Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Test the webhook handler by introducing controlled errors and verifying that they are logged correctly without affecting the server's stability.

tasks.title: Implement Outgoing Message Sending

tasks.testStrategy: Send test messages to a verified WhatsApp number and verify delivery and status updates.

Obtain API credentials from the WhatsApp Business Account. Set up the necessary environment configurations to securely store and access these credentials. Ensure the API is accessible from the system and test basic connectivity.

subtasks.title: Develop Text Message Sending Functionality

subtasks.details:
Implement a function that constructs and sends a text message payload to the WhatsApp Cloud API. Ensure the function handles API responses and errors appropriately. Include logging for message sending attempts.

Successfully created WhatsAppNotificationService that extends the base NotificationService. Implemented sendNotification for text messages, added to NotificationServiceFactory, and included support for rich formatting. subtasks.title: Implement Rich Media Message Sending

Modify the existing message sending function to handle different media types. Use the WhatsApp Cloud API's media upload feature to send images, documents, and other supported media. Ensure proper error handling and logging.
<info added on 2025-08-09T16:50:12.875Z>
The WhatsAppNotificationService now includes a sendMediaMessage method that supports sending images, documents, audio, and video files with optional captions. This method handles all media types supported by the WhatsApp Cloud API.

subtasks.title: Create Message Templates for Business-Initiated Conversations
subtasks.description: Develop and register message templates for initiating business conversations with users.
subtasks.details:
Design message templates that comply with WhatsApp's template guidelines. Use the WhatsApp Cloud API to register these templates. Implement functionality to select and send these templates when initiating conversations.
<info added on 2025-08-09T16:50:35.692Z>
The WhatsAppNotificationService includes a sendTemplateMessage method. subtasks.title: Implement Message Delivery Status Tracking
subtasks.description: Track and update the delivery status of messages sent to WhatsApp users.
subtasks.details:
Set up webhook endpoints to receive delivery status updates from the WhatsApp Cloud API. Implement logic to update message status in the system based on webhook notifications. Ensure accurate tracking of message states such as sent, delivered, and read.
<info added on 2025-08-09T16:53:05.096Z>
Successfully implemented message delivery status tracking. Added handleMessageStatusUpdate function in webhook handler to process WhatsApp status updates (sent, delivered, read, failed). Created updateWhatsAppMessageStatus procedure in integration router. Updated WhatsAppNotificationService to log outbound messages for tracking. System now tracks full message lifecycle.
</info added on 2025-08-09T16:53:05.096Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Send messages and verify that delivery status updates are correctly received and processed by the system.

tasks.title: Integrate Paddy AI Assistant
tasks.description: Enable natural language conversations with the AI assistant via WhatsApp.
tasks.details: Integrate the existing AI assistant 'Paddy' to handle natural language processing for WhatsApp messages. Implement context-aware responses and multi-turn conversation management.
tasks.testStrategy: Test AI interactions by sending various queries and verifying context-aware responses.

subtasks.title: Set Up WhatsApp API Integration
subtasks.description: Configure the WhatsApp Business API to enable message exchange with the AI assistant.
subtasks.details:
Register with the WhatsApp Business API and obtain the necessary credentials. Set up the API client to send and receive messages. Ensure that the webhook URL is correctly configured to receive incoming messages from WhatsApp.
<info added on 2025-08-09T17:53:56.291Z>
The WhatsApp Business API is fully configured with webhook endpoints at /api/webhooks/whatsapp handling incoming messages and WhatsAppNotificationService handling outgoing messages.
</info added on 2025-08-09T17:53:56.291Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify the API setup by sending test messages from WhatsApp and checking if they are received by the server.

subtasks.title: Integrate Paddy AI with WhatsApp Message Processing
subtasks.description: Connect the Paddy AI assistant to process incoming WhatsApp messages and generate responses.
subtasks.details:
Use the webhook handler to forward incoming messages to the Paddy AI assistant. Implement the logic to parse the message content and pass it to the AI for processing. Ensure that the AI's responses are formatted correctly for WhatsApp.
<info added on 2025-08-09T17:56:48.795Z>
Successfully integrated the AI assistant with WhatsApp. Updated the webhook handler to route incoming text messages to the AI chat system. Implemented the processAIMessage function using ChatOpenAI with Langchain, incorporating user action tools, maintaining conversation context, and sending responses back via WhatsApp. Users mapped to phone numbers can now chat with the AI assistant through WhatsApp.
</info added on 2025-08-09T17:56:48.795Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Send various types of messages to the WhatsApp number and verify that Paddy AI processes them and returns appropriate responses.

subtasks.title: Implement Context-Aware Response Handling
subtasks.description: Enhance the AI assistant's ability to maintain context across multiple message exchanges.
subtasks.details:

subtasks.title: Develop Error Handling and Fall-back Mechanisms
subtasks.description: Implement robust error handling and fall-back strategies for message processing failures.

<info added on 2025-08-09T19:23:27.683Z>
Implemented a comprehensive error handling system with the following components: 

1. An ErrorHandlingService that includes typed errors, fallback messages, retry logic, rate limiting, and error logging to a database.
2. A circuit breaker pattern to prevent cascading failures in WhatsApp API, AI processing, and database operations.
3. A health check endpoint at /api/webhooks/whatsapp/health to monitor system status, error rates, and circuit breaker states.
4. An enhanced webhook with validation, retries, proper error tracking, and user-friendly fallback messages.

The system now gracefully handles all identified failure points.
